title: More than 300 whales dead as rescuers scramble to save the rest at Farewell Spit - Yahoo New Zealand

locations.name: farewell spit - yahoo new zealand whale

text:
Whale rescue: Setback as refloated whales head back to beach, 300 dead at Farewell Spit Yahoo New Zealand Share Share More than 300 whales dead as rescuers scramble to save the rest at Farewell Spit - Yahoo New Zealand Whale rescuers have suffered a major setback as refloated whales begin to head back into the bay. Close 300 whales died after mass whale stranding UP NEXT VIDEO There's been a mass whale stranding off New Zealand's south island. Authorities say 417 pilot whales have been beached and 300 have died. Source: 7 News 300 whales died after mass whale stranding 
Only 100 pilot whales survived after 416 whales were stranded on Thursday night at Farewell Spit in Tasman. 
This morning's events is the one of the largest mass stranding in the country's history, with more than 300 whales now dead on the beach. 
The Department of Conservation Golden Bay operations manager Andrew Lamason said the refloated whales are now swimming in the wrong direction and heading back to shore. 
It was hoped the 10.30am high tide would help push the whales back out to sea, as rescuers wouldn't have another chance to refloat the whales until Saturday's high tide. 
Hundreds have responded to Project Jonah's call to help keep alive and refloat the whales that are stranded on Golden bay's northern beach. 
DOC spokesman Mike Ogle said high tide is at 10.30am so the next few hours were critical. 
"Inside beach of Farewell Spit, 1km up from Triangle Flat (base of Spit car park). High tide at 10.30am so need people there as soon as possible." The whales have beached themselves at Farewell Spit, in Tasman. Photo: Google Maps 
Those helping with the rescue have been told to bring wet suits, food and water with the mission expecting to take some hours. — Cheree Phillips (@Chazza1014) February 9, 2017 
Lamasan has asked rubber neckers to stay away, saying they'd prefer to be in the business of saving whales and not people. 
A team of 30 trained medics were headed to the site, with a number of volunteers putting their hand up to help. 
The long, curving spit is a prime site for whale strandings. 
It is the third-largest stranding on record. A thousand whales stranded on the Chathams in 1918. Close 'A lot of help needed': Rescuers scramble to save stranded whales UP NEXT Share Share More than 300 whales dead as rescuers scramble to save the rest at Farewell Spit - Yahoo New Zealand More News From Around NZ
